subject: Real Estate
title: Redlining's Lasting Shadow
description: A quick, practical guide to Redlining's Lasting Shadow.

hook.text: In the 1930s, the U.S. government drew red lines on maps around Black neighborhoods. Banks refused to lend there.

buildup.text: The Home Owners' Loan Corporation rated neighborhoods A through D. D-rated areas â€” redlined â€” got no credit.

discovery.text: Without mortgages, homeownership was impossible. Property values collapsed and never recovered for decades.

twist.text: Redlined neighborhoods in the 1930s are still poorer and less healthy than A-rated neighborhoods today.

climax.text: Redlining was outlawed in 1968, but its economic scars remain visible in every American city's map.

punchline.text: Lines drawn in the 1930s still shape neighborhoods today.
